snippet: To the Editor:   In "Affirmative Action and the Voter" (Op-Ed, July 31), Louis Harris uses the usual obfuscatory Newspeak, which substitutes "unqualified" for "less qualified," implies that the new preferences are not preferences at all and sugges...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In "Affirmative Action and the Voter" (Op-Ed, July 31), Louis Harris uses the usual obfuscatory Newspeak, which substitutes "unqualified" for "less qualified," implies that the new preferences are not preferences at all and suggests that it is possible to give an advantage to one person without disadvantaging another. That is patently impossible and the big lie at the heart of what today is called "affirmative action."

headline.main: Californians Can Put Civil Rights Back on Track
